doc.ContractDescription: THE AUTHOR PROPOSES THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN AUTOMATED CONSTRUCTION SYSTEM FOR HEDS APPLICATIONS WHICH WILL IMPLEMENT A GAMECHANGING MATERIAL RESOURCE STRATEGY COMBINED WITH AN INNOVATIVE ADAPTATION OF STATE OF THE ART ADDITIVE MANUFACTURING (AM) TECHNOLOGY. IN SITU RESOURCE UTILIZATION (ISRU) IS ACHIEVED BY RELYING ON TWO ELEMENTS WHICH ARE READILY AVAILABLE ON THE LUNAR AND MARTIAN SURFACES- SOLAR ENERGY AND REGOLITH- IN A PROCESS THAT CAN BE APPLIED ENDLESSLY, ALLOWING THE FORMATION OF CONTINUOUS LOAD BEARING AND ENCLOSING STRUCTURES, SUCH AS ROADS, BERMS, LANDING PADS, HABITATS, AND GARAGES. THE IMMEDIATE CHALLENGES PRESENTED BY IN SITU SINTERING ARE MANY. RADIATION, EXTREME TEMPERATURES, AND WIND COULD EASILY DISRUPT CONTINUOUS SINTERING AND CAUSE PROBLEMS FOR STRUCTURAL CONTINUITY AND RELIABLE MATERIAL DEPOSITION. BECAUSE OF THIS, A DIFFERENT APPROACH CAN BE TAKEN: FORMING AND ASSEMBLY OF REGOLITH BUILDING BLOCKS. A SIMILAR MOBILE CONSTRUCTION APPARATUS WOULD BE DEVELOPED, INTEGRATING SOLAR HARVESTING, REGOLITH BLOCK FORMING, AND AUTOMATED BLOCK ASSEMBLY. THE MAIN CHALLENGES (DELIVERABLES) WOULD BE THE FOLLOWING -DEVELOPMENT OF LOW POWER REGOLITH MOLDING/CASTING METHODOLOGY AND APPARATUS -CHARACTERIZATION OF BUILDING BLOCK GEOMETRY, MECHANICAL PROPERTIES, AND ASSEMBLY STRATEGY. -TESTING OF AUTOMATED BUILDING BLOCK ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY VIA MULTI-DOF SYSTEM (3 DOF GANTRY-BASED, 6 DOF KUKA OR SIMILAR ARMATURE FOR PICK AND PLACE APPROACH) -DEVELOPMENT OF OVERALL ISRU ASSEMBLY ROBOT DESIGN (POTENTIAL FOR PROTOTYPING)
GBS TGRS - DELL E6440 LAPTOP WITH MEDIA KITS DELIVERY DATE MODIFICATION
CHANGING ACCEPTANCE AND INSPECTION FROM ORIGIN TO DESTINATION.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO DELETE CLAUSE DFARS 252.11-7007 THAT IS NOT NEEDED.

doc.ContractDescription: MECHANICAL LOADING IS REQUIRED FOR MAINTENANCE OF THE MUSCULOSKELETAL SYSTEM. THUS, EXPOSURE TO MICROGRAVITY INDUCES MARKED BONE LOSS IN BOTH HUMANS AND ANIMALS, AND IS A MAJOR CONCERN FOR ASTRONAUTS EXPOSED TO LONG DURATION SPACEFLIGHT, AS THEY MAY BE AT INCREASED RISK FOR SKELETAL FRAGILITY AND BONE FRACTURES. MOST PRIOR STUDIES HAVE RELIED ON DUAL ENERGY XRAY ABSORPTIOMETRY (DXA), A 2D TECHNIQUE USED TO ASSESS BONE MASS AT DIFFERENT SKELETAL SITES, TO ASSESS EFFECTS OF SPACEFLIGHT ON BONE STRENGTH AND FRACTURE RISK. HOWEVER, DXA BASED MEASUREMENTS ARE LIMITED IN SEVERAL REGARDS. FIRST, WHOLE BONE STRENGTH IS DETERMINED BY BONE MASS, BONE GEOMETRY AND INTRINSIC PROPERTIES OF THE BONE MATRIX AND DXA IS ONLY ABLE TO ASSESS BONE MASS. SECOND, DXA MEASUREMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO TECHNICAL ARTIFACTS DUE TO OVERLYING STRUCTURES (E.G., AORTIC CALCIFICATION), DEGENERATIVE CHANGES (E.G., OSTEOPHYTES), AND DIFFERENCES IN BODY SIZE BETWEEN INDIVIDUALS AND WITHIN AN INDIVIDUAL OVER TIME. THIRD, DXA MEASUREMENTS ARE INADEQUATE FOR IDENTIFYING MECHANISMS UNDERLYING SKELETAL FRAGILITY, AS THEY CANNOT DISTINGUISH CHANGES IN TRABECULAR VERSUS CORTICAL BONE. NEWER TECHNOLOGIES, INCLUDING 3D QUANTITATIVE COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY (QCT) ARE ABLE TO OVERCOME THE LIMITATIONS OF DXA. MOREOVER, QCT IMAGES CAN BE USED TO ESTIMATE BONE STRENGTH USING A STANDARD ENGINEERING APPROACH CALLED FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS. INDEED, QCT IMAGES HAVE BEEN USED SUCCESSFULLY TO DEMONSTRATE NEGATIVE EFFECTS OF SPACEFLIGHT ON HIP BONE DENSITY AND STRENGTH. HOWEVER, A SIMILAR EXAMINATION OF THE EFFECTS OF SPACEFLIGHT ON VERTEBRAL STRENGTH HAS NOT BEEN PERFORMED. THUS THE DEGREE OF SPINAL DECONDITIONING AND SUBSEQUENT RISK OF VERTEBRAL FRACTURE FOLLOWING LONG DURATION SPACEFLIGHT REMAINS UNKNOWN. OUR CENTRAL OBJECTIVE IS TO ADDRESS THIS GAP IN KNOWLEDGE BY ASSESSING CHANGES IN VOLUMETRIC BONE DENSITY AND STRENGTH OF LUMBAR VERTEBRAE USING PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED QCT SCANS FROM LONG DURATION ISS CREWMEMBERS. IN ADDITION, SINCE BONE FRACTURES OCCUR WHEN THE FORCES APPLIED TO THE BONE EXCEED ITS STRENGTH, WE WILL ALSO ESTIMATE THE RISK OF SPINE FRACTURE BY COMPUTING A LOAD TO STRENGTH RATIO IN EACH ASTRONAUT FOR DIFFERENT ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING. VERTEBRAL STRENGTH WILL BE MEASURED USING AN FDA APPROVED METHOD THAT EMPLOYS FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSES OF QCT SCANS, AND HAS BEEN VALIDATED AGAINST IN VITRO BONE STRENGTH TESTING AS WELL AS IN LARGE, POPULATION BASED STUDIES OF SPINE FRACTURE. WE WILL ESTIMATE LOADS APPLIED TO THE SPINE USING A MUSCULOSKELETAL MODEL OF THE LUMBAR AND THORACIC SPINE THAT CAN BE ADJUSTED TO REFLECT THE ASTRONAUTS HEIGHT, WEIGHT, SPINAL SHAPE AND SPECIFIC TRUNK MUSCLE ANATOMY ALL FACTORS THAT ARE IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTORS TO SPINAL LOADING. THIS WORK IS HIGHLY SIGNIFICANT TO NASA AS BONE LOSS AND INCREASED FRACTURE RISK FOLLOWING LONG DURATION SPACEFLIGHT REMAIN KEY OPERATIONAL CONCERNS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROPOSAL DIRECTLY ADDRESSES SEVERAL RISKS OUTLINES IN THE HUMAN RESEARCH PROGRAM (HRP) PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS DOCUMENT FROM 2009 1) RISK OF INJURY FROM DYNAMIC LOADS 2) RISK OF BONE FRACTURE AND 3) RISK OF EARLY ONSET OSTEOPOROSIS DUE TO SPACEFLIGHT. FURTHER, THE PROPOSED WORK ADDRESSES SEVERAL GAPS IDENTIFIED IN THE INTEGRATED RESEARCH PLAN, INCLUDING 1) OP5 WE DO NOT KNOW THE EXTENT TO WHICH SPACEFLIGHT DECONDITIONING DECREASES INJURY TOLERANCE FOR DYNAMIC LOADS 2) FRACTURE 3 WE NEED A VALIDATED METHOD TO ESTIMATE THE RISK OF FRACTURE BY EVALUATING THE RATIO OF APPLIED LOADS TO BONE FRACTURE LOADS AND 3) OSTEO 3 WE NEED A VALIDATED CLINICALLY RELEVANT METHOD FOR ASSESSING THE EFFECT OF SPACEFLIGHT ON OSTEOPOROSIS OR FRACTURE RISK IN LONG DURATION ASTRONAUTS. IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECTS OF SPACEFLIGHT ON VERTEBRAL FRAGILITY AND SPINAL LOADING WILL ALLOW DEVELOPMENT OF EFFECTIVE COUNTERMEASURES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF BONE FRACTURE IN ASTRONAUTS, AND MAY LEAD TO IMPROVEMENTS IN ASSESSMENT OF SPINE FRACTURE RISK IN OLDER ADULTS.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE A COLLABORATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN MIT AND THE NASA GODDARD INSTITUTE FOR SPACE SCIENCE (GISS) IN NEW YORK. THE PROGRAM BRINGS TOGETHER THE EXPERTISE OF MIT IN OCEAN DYNAMICS AND OCEAN MODELING WITH THAT OF GISS IN COUPLED CLIMATE MODELING. THE RESEARCH IS DIRECTED AT (I) COORDINATING OCEAN MODELING ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE CURRENT OCEAN MODELS BEING DEVELOPED AT GISS AND (II) APPLYING THEM IN THE GISS COUPLED MODELING FRAMEWORK TO LEARN ABOUT HOW FEEDBACKS BETWEEN THE ATMOSPHERE AND OCEAN AFFECT NATURAL VARIABILITY AND SHAPE THE RESPONSE OF THE CLIMATE SYSTEM TO ANTHROPOGENIC FORCING. IN PARTICULAR THE MIT-GISS COLLABORATION WILL FOCUS ON: 1. IMPROVING THE DYNAMICAL KERNEL OF THE GISS OCEAN MODEL SO THAT IT CAN BE USED ACROSS SCALE (INCLUDING EDDY-RESOLVING) WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON POLAR PROCESSES AND THE INTERACTION OF OCEAN AND ICE. 2. USING THE RESULTING MODELS TO EXPLORE THE ROBUSTNESS OF THE RESPONSE OF THE COUPLED SYSTEM TO TRANSIENT (I.E. DECADAL TO CENTENNIAL) GREENHOUSE GAS AND OZONE CLIMATE FORCING, WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON THE POLAR CAPS. THE GISS MODEL-E DEPLOYED IN STUDIES OF CLIMATE CHANGE WILL PROVIDE THE MODELING CONTEXT BUT, WHERE APPROPRIATE, MODELS DEVELOPED AT MIT WILL ALSO BE USED.
doc.MajorAgency: RESEARCH THE NATURAL VARIABILITY OF CLIMATE AND TH

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF GINER, INC. PROPOSES TO DEMONSTRATE THE FEASIBILITY OF DEVELOPING AN IMPROVED ELECTROCHEMICAL PROCESS FOR THE REMOVAL CO2 FROM CABIN AIR, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING FOR RECYCLING OF WATER AND PROVISION OF O2. THIS NEW PROCESS SEEKS TO MORE EFFICIENTLY COMBINE THE CURRENT FUNCTIONS OF STANDARD WATER ELECTROLYSIS FOR BREATHING O2 PRODUCTION AND THE SABATIER PROCESS FOR REMOVAL OF CABIN CO2. IT REPRESENTS A MAJOR INNOVATION AND PARADIGM SHIFT, RATHER THAN A MINOR ENHANCEMENT OF EXISTING PROCESSES. THE PROCESS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED USING A NOVEL ELECTROCHEMICAL CO2 REDUCTION ELECTROCATALYST IN CONJUNCTION WITH A PROTON-EXCHANGE MEMBRANE ELECTROCHEMICAL CELL. THIS TECHNOLOGY IS EXPECTED TO HAVE DIRECT APPLICATIONS FOR HUMAN EXPLORATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF SPACE MISSIONS AS A MEANS FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND REMOVAL OF EXCESS RESPIRED CARBON DIOXIDE SPACE CABINS AND ENHANCED CLOSED-LOOP OPERATIONS ON LONG DURATION MISSIONS. THE PROPOSED PROCESS WILL ENHANCE THE CLOSED-LOOP BY RECYCLING CONSIDERABLE AMOUNTS OF WATER AND WILL PROVIDE LAUNCH-MASS SAVING. THE PROPOSED PROCESS NOT ONLY WILL REDUCE CO2, BUT WILL ALSO PRODUCE WATER AND ORGANIC FUEL; THE WATER WILL BE ELECTROLYZED TO O2 AND THE LIQUID FUEL OF WILL BE CAPTURED AND STORED FOR USE. THE PHASE I TECHNICAL OBJECTIVES ARE TO DEMONSTRATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF A NOVEL SPECIALTY CATHODE CATALYST FOR CARBON DIOXIDE REDUCTION THAT RESULTS IN THE PRODUCTION OF WATER AND METHANOL, DEVELOP AN EFFICIENT CATHODE ELECTRODE STRUCTURE, FABRICATE A COMPLETE ELECTROCHEMICAL REACTOR, AND TO OPERATE THE REACTOR UNDER A WIDE VARIETY OF CONDITIONS. THE PHASE I CONCLUDES WITH A DESIGN FOR A COMPLETE, INTEGRATED SYSTEM FOR OXYGEN GENERATION AND CARBON DIOXIDE AND WATER RECYCLING.

doc.ContractDescription: WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX INDICES OF REFRACTION OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIALS FOR ACCURATE AEROSOL AND GAS RETRIEVALS BY SATELLITE INSTRUMENTATION, RECENT CLOSURE STUDIES HAVE EMPHASIZED THE HIGH PRIORITY OF OBTAINING IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF ATMOSPHERIC ORGANIC AEROSOLS. THIS PRIORITY IS MOTIVATED NOT ONLY BY THE NEED FOR ACCURATE RETRIEVALS OF AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH BUT ALSO BY THE NEED FOR ACCURATE RETRIEVALS OF ATMOSPHERIC GAS CONCENTRATIONS, WHICH MUST INCLUDE COMPENSATION FOR AEROSOL EXTINCTION. THE SUBMICRON FRACTION OF ATMOSPHERIC AEROSOLS, WHICH HAS A HIGHER MASS EXTINCTION EFFICIENCY FOR ULTRAVIOLET AND VISIBLE WAVELENGTHS THAN THE SUPERMICRON FRACTION, IS DOMINATED IN MANY REGIONS OF THE WORLD AND AT MANY TIMES BY SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOLS (SOA), YET THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF THESE AEROSOLS ARE LITTLE INVESTIGATED. MOREOVER, THESE PROPERTIES DEPEND IN YET UNKNOWN WAYS ON THE MOLECULAR PRECURSOR TO THE SOA AND THE DOMINANT OXIDATION PATHWAYS LEADING TO SOA FORMATION. THE COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF THE MATERIALS CONSTITUTING THE AEROSOLS ARE A FUNDAMENTAL FACTOR UNDERLYING THE OPTICAL PROPERTIES. IN ADDITION TO LIGHT SCATTERING, RECENT LABORATORY STUDIES AND ATMOSPHERIC OBSERVATIONS HAVE SHOWN THAT THESE AEROSOLS HAVE IMPORTANT ABSORPTIVE COMPONENTS UNDER SOME CIRCUMSTANCES. THE GOALS OF THE PROPOSED WORK ARE BOTH TO OBTAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE TARGETED AT REDUCING THE UNCERTAINTIES SURROUNDING THE FOREGOING ISSUES AND TO IMPLEMENT THIS NEW QUANTITATIVE INFORMATION IN UPDATED SATELLITE RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS. THE ASSOCIATED OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. TO MEASURE THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL; 2. TO DETERMINE AND THEN TO MODEL THE CHEMICAL FACTORS THAT CONTROL VARIABILITY OF THE REFRACTIVE INDICES AMONG DIFFERENT TYPES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL; AND 3. TO USE THE LABORATORY DATA OF PARTS 1 AND 2 TO TEST THE SENSITIVITIES OF SATELLITE RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS TO VARIABLE ORGANIC AEROSOLS, WITH THE ULTIMATE AIM TO UPDATE THE ACCURACY OF THE OPERATIONAL ALGORITHMS. IN THE WORK TO BE PERFORMED, DIFFERENT TYPES OF SOA WILL BE PRODUCED IN THE HARVARD ENVIRONMENTAL CHAMBER (MARTIN, PI). GASEOUS PRECURSORS WILL REPRESENT BOTH BIOGENIC EMISSIONS (E.G., ISOPRENE, ALPHA-PINENE, BETA-CARYOPHYLLENE, LIMONENE, AND SO FORTH) AND ANTHROPOGENIC EMISSIONS (E.G., TOLUENE, XYLENES, AND SO FORTH). IN A SERIES OF PHOTO-OXIDATION EXPERIMENTS, NOX-, HO2-, AND RO2-DOMINANT REACTION REGIMES WILL BE PROBED BY ADJUSTING THE RELATIVE RATIOS OF NOX:HO2:RO2, AS MODELED BY THE MASTER CHEMICAL MECHANISM COUPLED TO A CONDENSATION MODEL (MCM-SIMPOL). DARK OZONOLYSIS EXPERIMENTS WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED. SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL WILL BE DEPOSITED AS THIN FILMS ONTO SILICON SUBSTRATES, AND THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF THE MATERIAL WILL BE MEASURED USING SPECTROSCOPIC ELLIPSOMETRY. THE THIN-FILM RESULTS WILL BE VALIDATED FOR THE AEROSOL BY USING CAVITY RING-DOWN SPECTROSCOPY AT A SINGLE WAVELENGTH WITH COLLABORATOR FREEDMAN. A RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL WILL EMPLOY THE REFRACTIVE INDICES TO SIMULATE SATELLITE RETRIEVALS AND THEREBY INVESTIGATE THE SENSITIVITIES OF ATMOSPHERIC GAS ABUNDANCE RETRIEVALS AT THE ULTRAVIOLET AND VISIBLE WAVELENGTHS TO AEROSOL PHYSICAL PROPERTIES (CHANCE, CO-PI). GASES WILL INCLUDE OZONE, SULFUR DIOXIDE, FORMALDEHYDE, NITROGEN DIOXIDE, AND GLYOXAL. IN COLLABORATION WITH TORRES, THE DATA SETS WILL ALSO BE TESTED FOR THEIR INFLUENCE ON OPERATIONAL SATELLITE RETRIEVAL SCHEMES, ESPECIALLY HOW THE NEW DATA SETS FOR ORGANIC AEROSOL CAN IMPROVE CLOSURE BETWEEN SATELLITE RETRIEVALS AND GROUND-BASED OBSERVATIONS. INITIAL TARGETS WILL BE THE OMAERUV AND OMAERO RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS FOR AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH AND AEROSOL ABSORPTION OPTICAL DEPTH BASED ON THE TOP-OF-ATMOSPHERE REFLECTANCE MEASURED BY OMI. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL ASSIST NASA IN REALIZATION OF OBJECTIVE 2.1.1 OF ITS STRAT
doc.ParentRecipientOrCompanyName: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

doc.ProductorServiceCode: 2840: GAS TURBINES AND JET ENGINES, AIRCRAFT, PRIME MOVING; AND COMPONENTS
